Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a strong interest across the U.S. to understand how students enter, exit and persist in pathways toward science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) degrees and careers. However, we still do not have a very strong understanding of how students enter into STEM, how they persist and why they follow certain paths to a degree or career in these technical fields. This study proposes to add to our knowledge of how students proceed in two key areas: high school course taking and the higher education to career transition. Additionally, the project seeks to create data tools that will make it easier for educators, researchers and policymakers to visualize pathways and identify groups of individuals pursuing specific paths and to share key findings with the public through a simple interface and intuitive visualizations.

The research will use data on students and the workforce collected by the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) and the National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics (NCSES). These datasets will be used to identify current and past trends in high school student course-taking patterns and allow for making a prediction about the number of students who will pursue STEM in college and university based on these patterns. By using nationally representative data collected by the federal government to investigate these issues across groups based on age, sex, minority status and disability status, the results will provide the ability for critical comparisons of differences in pathways and highlight possible opportunities for intervention. The completed data tool modules will be made available and maintained as part of the NSF-funded Sci2Tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a strong interest across the U.S. to understand how individuals enter, exit and persist in pathways toward science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) degrees and careers. However, we still do not have a very strong understanding of how students enter into STEM, how they persist and why they follow certain paths to a degree or career in these technical fields.

There were three main goals for this project. First, we sought to update and advance work related to investigating the high school course-taking patterns of students from nationally representative samples of students in the US. These analyses were based on restricted access transcript data from the National Center for Education Statistics going back to 1988. We were not able to advance this goal based on the complexity of addressing the other goals of the project.

Second, we sought to use National Survey of College Graduates and SESTAT data provided by NSF, for analysis of patterns in degree completion, workforce entry and persistence using with various data elements collected over time going back to 1993.  These longitudinal data were collected from nationally representative samples that enable the evaluation of the dynamics of changes in pathways from school to career in STEM over time. These data also allow for exploration of workforce related changes over time (e.g., salaries).

With this funding we advanced three separate analyses toward meeting this goal. First, we used the data to provide descriptive statistics related to the academic attainment and workforce entry patterns across STEM fields over the last 25 years. One finding from this was that for Computer and Mathematical Sciences, approximately one third of the group who earned degrees in CMS work in these fields, one third who earned degrees work outside of these fields and one third of those working in these fields came from academic pathways that did not include degrees in these fields. Other disciplines have a much tighter coupling between those who earn degrees and those who work in those fields. Second, we used the career field and salary data to investigate changes in salaries over time and difference between males and females. This analysis indicated quite significant differences, as we would expect, across fields, but rather consistent over time. This analysis we are working to advance more to publication. Third, we started exploring longitudinal data to conduct survival analyses investigating the factors that lead to individuals remaining in STEM longer.    

 

Finally, the project sought to create data tools that make it easier for educators, researchers and policymakers to visualize pathways and identify groups of individuals pursuing specific paths and to share key findings with the public through a simple interface and intuitive visualizations.

 

We were able to move far along toward creating a working prototype for a small selection of SESTAT longitudinal data. However, we did not get to do usability testing, because the programming group used up their full budget in design and revision. It seems that this tool is still needed by the research community and that further funding can make a tool usable by researchers.
